希望从印度经济增长中获利的投资者通常要么将注意力集中在该国大亨经营的庞大企业集团上，要么将注意力集中在改变印度人购物、学习或出行方式的热闹科技公司上。那么，如何解释 Cello World 这家拥有 61 年历史的中等规模公司于 11 月 6 日在当地两家交易所上市的兴奋之情呢？它生产印度人用来携带午餐去学校或工作的“午餐盒”，以及廉价的钢笔和模制家具——这些东西都没什么令人兴奋的。然而，其股价在交易首日就飙升了 29%，市值超过 20 亿美元。这几乎是上一财年净利润的 60 倍。其首次公开募股 ( IPO ) 获得约 40 倍的超额认购。

Cello World 没有大胆的计划将此次发行筹集的 2.3 亿美元进行再投资；所有这些都将回到控制该公司的家族手中，该家族仍拥有 81% 的股权。该业务也不是独一无二的。上月底，另一家钢笔制造公司 Flairwriting Industries 获得了首次公开募股的批准。几家家具公司也准备在不久的将来发行股票。简而言之，大提琴世界相当无聊。

很少有风险投资家愿意排队购买这样一家企业的股份。外国投资组合经理中的许多人已经确定了通过在印度最强大的企业集团中持有少量股份进入印度的战略，但他们也可能会放弃这一计划。然而，最近几个月的情况表明，印度经济中最有吸引力的部分之一可能是像 Cello World 这样的公司，它们正在从该国的增长故事中受益，而不是试图书写它。

从去年年底开始，由于投资者对连锁酒店OYO和在线学习公司 Byju's 等亏损的初创公司失去了耐心，印度私募市场的估值暴跌。公共市场也下跌。物流初创公司 Delhivery 于 2022 年初大张旗鼓地上市，其股价暴跌。今年1月，卖空者兴登堡针对印度大亨高塔姆·阿达尼商业帝国会计实务的一份报告，动摇了外国投资者的信心，并引起人们对印度多家企业集团盈利能力疲弱的关注。 。 （阿达尼集团否认有任何不当行为。）

情绪转变的第一个迹象是 4 月份，避孕套和妊娠测试产品制造商 Mankind Pharma 上市。该公司以其稳定的收入增长（从 2020 年的约 7.5 亿美元增至 2022 年的 10 亿美元）和健康的利润吸引了投资者。人们很快就发现，在经历超常增长的经济体的普通领域，有吸引力的机会比比皆是。

随后出现了大量的清单。截至 11 月初，今年已有 194 家公司上市，高于 2022 年全年的 144 家公司（见图表）。投资银行杰富瑞 (Jefferies) 计算出，近期印度IPO中 72% 的超额认购至少是十倍。除了 Cello World 和 Mankind Pharma 等消费品公司外，投资者还抢购了建筑、化工、钢铁和电气元件等其他通常不起眼的行业新上市公司的股票。尽管不处于技术前沿，但其中许多公司都受益于印度政府支持国内制造业（以中国为代价）和改善国家基础设施的努力。 9 月份上市的电缆制造商 RR Kabel 就是这样的公司之一。 11月6日，该公司报告称，7月至9月的季度利润同比翻了一番。

上市热潮没有放缓的迹象。另外 29 项公开发行申请已获得印度证券监管机构的批准，另有 46 项申请目前正在考虑中。正在发行股票的公司包括一家大锤生产商和一家汽车零部件制造商。所有人都希望在明年五月印度大选之前上市。 IIFL证券公司（一家为今年许多上市公司提供融资的投资银行）的 Nipun Goel 指出，未来 12 至 24 个月的IPO计划看起来很强劲；他打赌这种繁荣可能会持续五到七年。事实上，在十月份，考虑到这一切，他的公司搬到了空间三倍的新办公室。 ■

; Thu, 09 Nov 2023 09:09:47 GMT /内容/a43avvni1f4je9n0gh30l6ri50ddi3lv https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/09/india-is-in-the-mid-of-an-unusual-ipo-boom The fall of WeWork shows the deepening cracks in real estate

自2010年成立以来，WeWork从未实现过盈利。多年来，由于其浮夸的创始人亚当·诺依曼(Adam Neumann)扭曲现实的权力，它的现金火炬方式从未受到挑战，他成功地让投资者，尤其是软银，相信它不是一家办公室租赁公司，而是一家充满活力的科技公司。 “提升世界意识”的使命。 2019 年初，在首次公开募股 ( IPO ) 前夕，该公司的估值达到了 470 亿美元。

事情很快就开始瓦解，外部投资者对其泡沫般的估值犹豫不决，并对诺伊曼对公司实行铁腕控制的非正统治理安排提出质疑。首次公开募股被搁置，诺伊曼先生被提供 17 亿美元的离职条件。桑迪普·马特拉尼 (Sandeep Mathrani) 是一名房地产资深人士，被任命来管理该公司，他尽最大努力通过削减成本和重新谈判租赁来扭转局面。 2021年，他通过一家特殊目的收购公司成功将公司上市，估值为90亿美元。然而，由于疫情导致办公市场低迷以及向远程工作的持久转变，他的努力化为泡影。 11 月 6 日，WeWork 申请破产，该公司在 39 个国家的 777 个地点租赁办公空间。

这并不是唯一一家陷入动荡的房地产企业。几天前，在大西洋的另一边，曾经著名的奥地利房地产巨头雷内·本科(René Benko)被逐出了他一手打造的价值230亿欧元（合250亿美元）的房地产帝国西尼亚。其投资组合包括纽约克莱斯勒大厦； K a D e W e，西柏林的一家豪华百货商店；以及伦敦另一家豪华消费殿堂塞尔福里奇百货公司的股份；以及豪华酒店、高端开发项目和其他零售业务。

这两个案例并不完全相同。与 WeWork 不同的是，Signa 并未宣布破产，尽管它面临着流动性紧缩，并聘请了著名的德国破产专家阿恩特·盖维茨 (Arndt Geiwitz) 来接管。与诺伊曼先生不同的是，本科先生是一位白手起家的高中辍学生，他的职业生涯始于将家乡因斯布鲁克的阁楼改造成顶层公寓，直到周末被赶下台之前，他一直参与西尼亚的事务。 2012 年因行贿罪被定罪后，他退出了日常运营职责，但继续担任公司顾问委员会成员。他对盖维茨先生的任命表示祝贺，盖维茨先生帮助德国国家航空公司汉莎航空度过了破产危机。 （与此同时，诺伊曼则只能在一旁对 WeWork 的倒闭进行冷嘲热讽，抱怨该公司“未能充分利用当今比以往任何时候都更重要的产品”。）

然而，这两个帝国的兴衰却有相似之处。其一，两者都依赖于高风险的赌注，但在利率上升和房地产市场低迷的世界中，这些赌注都失败了。在建立自己的帝国的过程中，本科先生积累了大量债务，以便在维持丰厚股息的同时购买新资产。这种模式只有在利率较低且优质房产价值持续上涨的情况下才有效。在WeWork的案例中，风险源于一种模式，即对房产进行长期租约，有时长达20年，斥巨资进行时髦的翻新，然后租用空间一次短至一个月。当写字楼市场转向时，该公司被迫支付远远超出其向租户收取的租金的租金，因为有更便宜的替代方案可供选择。

尽管如此，两个帝国都可能变得更加强大。因斯布鲁克大学的莱昂哈德·多布施 (Leonhard Dobusch) 认为，盖维茨将拆分西格纳庞大的投资组合，出售资产以获取现金并偿还债务。私营企业由数百家控股公司组成，需要进行一些简化。 WeWork 则已获得大多数债权人的支持，将其 30 亿美元的债务转换为股权，使其资产负债表近乎全新。它还将利用破产的机会终止在美国的 60 多项租约，并重新谈判其他租约。诺伊曼和本科可能会离开，但他们创建的公司很可能会持续下去。 ■

; Tue, 07 Nov 2023 21:41:24 GMT /内容/5g4lhmpmdtni0kh2lvknfluk39j61dlo https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/07/the-fall-of-wework-shows-the-deepening-cracks-in-real-estate How to manage teams in a world designed for individuals

团队中没有“我”。但“自动驾驶”中有一个。尽管团队合作在组织中的重要性日益增加，但用于管理员工的流程却与以前一样。老板们可能对合作赞不绝口，但他们奖励、审查和招聘的方式却没有跟上。

组织中的人们总是与其他人协同工作。但出于多种原因，对团队的重视正在日益增长。技术使想法和信息的共享变得更加容易，而混合工作则使其变得更加重要。 （它不被称为 Microsoft Silos 是有原因的。）软件行业已经将团队的福音——敏捷、scrums、 OKR以及所有其他内容——传播到了各个地方。

在我们新的七部分播客系列 《老板课堂》中，我们的巴图比专栏作家寻找成为更好经理的秘诀。第三集探讨如何正确招聘，第四集探讨如何打造一支优秀的团队。

麻省理工学院斯隆管理学院的阿卜杜拉·阿尔马图克最近发表的一篇论文表明，事实证明，团队更擅长解决复杂的问题。研究还表明，人们对工作团队的依恋程度高于对组织的依恋程度。你不太可能带着标志去吃午餐。

关于团队运作的因素的知识也在不断积累，这是本周我们新的管理播客《老板课堂》一集的主题。亚里士多德项目是谷歌对其表现最佳团队的特征进行的一项著名研究，该项目将“心理安全”（说出自己的想法的舒适度）确定为最重要的因素，此外还有可靠性、角色明确性和有意义的工作等。不同的团队擅长不同的事情。芝加哥大学的吴令飞及其合著者的分析发现，团队规模和科学研究类型之间存在相关性：较大的团队开发现有的想法，而较小的团队则用新的想法颠覆该领域。

但对团队的更多重视和理解通常不会转化为匹配的管理实践。招聘流程关注的是个人的成就，而不是他们所在的集体。绩效管理在很大程度上仍然是一项单人运动。评价通常基于个人目标，奖金也是如此。衡量标准通常仅限于具体的产出，而不是基于团队的软性衡量标准，例如人们的信任程度。许多老板根本不知道他们的团队到底在做什么，这也于事无补。软件公司 Soroco 以及哈佛商学院和宾夕法尼亚大学沃顿商学院的学者要求管理者描述他们认为占用团队大部分时间的流程。平均而言，他们不知道或记不起团队成员 60% 的工作，这使得他们更像是高效能的金鱼，而不是老板。

其中大部分都是有充分理由的。人是一一调职、升迁的，不是以营的形式。根据团队绩效奖励员工可能会导致不公平：搭便车的人可能会得到太多的认可，或者努力工作的人可能会因为其他人没有尽职尽责而受到惩罚。量化团队贡献是很困难的。当团队由来自不同部门的人员组成或组建时间有限时，管理者会发现很难知道他们的直接下属在做什么。

但这些问题并非无法克服。在招聘人员时，可以评估成为优秀团队成员的特质：例如，在一项要求参与者通过眼睛快照确定人们感受的测试中取得良好成绩与成为一名优秀的团队合作者相关。同行评审可以很好地了解人们在团队中的形象。

关于基于团队的奖金可能会鼓励搭便车的担忧似乎也被夸大了。奥胡斯大学的安德斯·弗雷德里克森（Anders Frederiksen）和他的合著者最近进行了一项研究，研究了在制造公司引入基于群体的激励措施的影响，发现它引发了绩效的巨大飞跃。这种跳跃不仅是因为该计划激励现有员工提高效率，还因为它吸引了更具生产力的新员工。

员工是个人；管理者永远不应该忘记这一点。但如果团队是很多奇迹发生的地方，老板们应该有更好的方法来充分利用他们。弄清楚他们整天都在做什么可能是一个很好的起点。 ■

; Mon, 06 Nov 2023 18:06:43 GMT /内容/c86cqlbjvfm045obl9t3550s8va7or23 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/06/how-to-manage-teams-in-a-world-Designed-for-individuals Silicon Valley is piling into the business of snooping

九月初，纽约人可能已经注意到一位不受欢迎的客人在他们的聚会周围徘徊。在劳动节周末前夕，纽约警察局 ( NYPD ) 表示将使用无人机来调查有关庆祝活动的投诉，包括后院聚会。警用无人机在美国进行窥探的现象越来越常见。根据西北普利兹克法学院研究人员最近的一项调查，大约四分之一的警察部队现在使用它们。

更令人惊讶的是这项技术的来源。 Skydio 是纽约市警察局的供应商之一，这是一家硅谷公司，该公司利用人工智能 ( AI ) 使无人机易于飞行，让警员无需接受任何培训即可控制无人机。 Skydio 得到了风险投资 ( VC ) 巨头 Andreessen Horowitz 和同行之一 Accel 的支持。纽约警察局还从另一家初创公司BRINC购买产品，该公司生产配备夜视摄像头的飞行器，可以粉碎窗户。 Chat GPT背后的初创公司 Open AI的 Sam Altman 是BRINC的投资者之一。

硅谷正在帮助美国执法部门窥探麻烦制造者，这似乎有些奇怪。支持国家监控与许多在互联网早期成长起来的美国科技名人所信奉的自由主义价值观格格不入。尽管硅谷在 20 世纪 50 年代就开始为美国国防工业供应芯片，但随着其注意力从导弹转向电子商务和 iPhone，它与国家的关系逐渐萎缩。

现在，随着科技行业寻求新的增长领域，向国家出售产品又重新流行起来。安德森霍洛维茨基金公司的凯瑟琳·博伊尔去年在一篇博客文章中写道，政府是“软件革命中最后的抵抗者”。今年早些时候，该公司推出了“美国活力”基金，投资于政府相关行业。国家正在缓慢但坚定地进入数字时代。 2022 年底，五角大楼向 Alphabet、亚马逊、甲骨文和微软四大科技巨头授予了一份价值 90 亿美元的云计算合同。根据《经济学人》的计算，去年授予企业的联邦合同价值中有 11% 是软件和技术，高于十年前的 8%。

监视是一项正在升级的政府活动。观察和分析的新技术正在改变这个领域。 Axon Enterprise 和 Motorola Solutions 等传统供应商向警方和其他安全组织销售摄像头和各种监控系统，现在也有新贵推出更先进的技术。

其中第一个是无人机。该行业一直由中国制造商大疆创新主导，去年美国销售的无人机近四分之三都由该公司生产。这引起了美国政府圈子的极大担忧。 11月1日，国会提出一项法案，禁止所有联邦政府部门购买中国无人机。包括佛罗里达州在内的一些州已经禁止紧急服务部门这样做。所有这一切对于 Skydio 和Brinc等公司来说都是福音。

其他类型的空中侦察设备也在研发中。另一家初创公司 Skydweller 正在开发一种自动太阳能飞机，这种飞机无需着陆即可充电。该公司表示，这将允许“持续监视”。

第二个方兴未艾的技术是卫星。埃隆·马斯克 (Elon Musk) 旗下的火箭公司 SpaceX 及其模仿者帮助将物体送入太空的成本降低到了二十年前水平的十分之一左右。这导致近地轨道上布满了卫星，其中大约八分之一的卫星用于观测地球。另一家风险投资公司 Founders Fund 的 Trae Stephens 表示，数据公司 PitchBook 估计现在有近 200 家公司从事卫星图像销售业务，数量如此之多，以至于市场已经商品化。其中一家公司 BlackSky 表示，它可以每隔一小时左右拍摄一张地球上某个地点的图像。自 2013 年以来，卫星图像已经取得了长足的进步，当时俄勒冈州警方利用 Google 地球的图片发现了居民院子里的非法大麻种植园。

技术人员还销售工具来帮助执法部门更好地利用现在触手可及的大量图像和信息。周围的。 AI是另一家由 Andreessen Horowitz 支持的初创公司，它开发了自动监控摄像头是否存在可疑活动的技术。 Palantir 是一家数据挖掘公司，已融入美国军工联合体，并将其工具出售给洛杉矶警察局等机构。

面部识别软件现在在美国也得到了更广泛的使用，大约十分之一的警察部队可以使用该技术。美国政府问责局9月份发布的一份报告发现，包括联邦调查局和特勤局在内的六个联邦执法机构平均每天一起执行69次面部识别搜索。列出的顶级供应商之一是 Clearview AI ，这是一家由风投资深人士 Peter Thiel 支持的公司。

硅窥探者

由于生成式人工智能能够处理图像和视频片段等“非结构化”数据，为聊天GPT提供支持的类型的生成式人工智能可能很快会进一步增强监控能力。卫星公司 Planet Labs 的老板威尔·马歇尔 (Will Marshall) 表示，利用该技术分析卫星图像将让用户“在地球上搜索物体”，就像谷歌让用户在互联网上搜索信息一样。

对于新来者来说，向政府出售巧妙的新监控技术并不容易。 Axon 的老板 Rick Smith 指出，美国有 18,000 个警察部门。其中五分之一不使用电子记录。直到 2009 年，纽约警察局仍在购买打字机。

对于真正站稳脚跟的新人来说，回报可能是丰厚的。安德森·霍洛维茨公司美国活力基金的负责人大卫·乌列维奇（David Ulevitch）观察到，口碑可以快速传播，创造“病毒式传播”。 Fusus 是一家销售实时犯罪监控软件的初创公司，该公司表示，尽管基数较低，但去年其销售额增长了 300% 以上。 2017 年，另一家初创公司 Flock Safety 推出了车牌阅读器，目前已在美国 47 个州使用。此外，另一家风险投资公司 General Catalyst 的 Paul Kwan 指出，与政府买家的关系一旦建立，往往会持续很长时间。

较大的公司正在适应。自 2019 年以来，摩托罗拉解决方案已进行 15 项收购，包括视频分析工具 Calipsa 和警车仪表板摄像头制造商 WatchGuard。 Axon 还收购了初创公司并入股了其他公司，包括 Fusus 和 Skydio。

将新技术魔法应用于监视公民的工作会让许多人感到不舒服。 2020 年，出于对隐私的担忧，亚马逊、微软和IBM停止向执法机构提供面部识别服务。但监控可能仍然有利可图，尤其是因为政府并不是这些技术的唯一客户。 Skydio 的无人机评估手机信号塔和桥梁的损坏情况。对冲基金利用卫星图像来统计零售商停车场的汽车数量，希望在市场披露之前衡量其收入。 SmartEye 是一家瑞典公司，销售眼球追踪技术来监控飞行员的情绪。它还将产品出售给广告公司。无论是老大哥还是大企业加强监控的趋势看起来都不太可能逆转。 ■

2021 年 9 月，阿尔弗雷德·斯特恩 (Alfred Stern) 就任OMV首席执行官时，用了一个词来形容奥地利的石油和天然气巨头：塑料。他之前负责管理该公司的化学品部门 Borealis，他认为OMV的未来是该业务，而不是化石燃料。全球对碳排放产品的需求迟早会达到峰值。预计到 2030 年，用于包装的原生塑料的年均增长率将达到 4.7%，快于世界GDP 的增长率；对于再生塑料来说，每年的增幅将高达 12%。

2022 年 2 月， OMV从俄罗斯购买大部分天然气，斯特恩先生在他的下属看来一定是有先见之明的，当时俄罗斯入侵了乌克兰。一个月后，他公开公布了他的新战略。从现在起，该公司将专注于生产和销售可持续燃料、化学品和材料——重点是“可持续”。它将逐渐减少石油和天然气的生产。 OMV的老板希望到本十年末，石油和天然气部门占集团营业利润的 30%，而 2019 年至 2021 年间的平均比例为 44%。化学品将占一半，高于29%。

即使在最好的情况下，这样的转变也是雄心勃勃的。由于全球能源、化学品和材料市场都受到地缘政治和经济力量的冲击，这似乎是无耻的——尤其是当其他石油和天然气公司正在修改其绿色计划并加倍投资原油时。

10 月 31 日， OMV表示，第三季度销售额与去年同期相比下降了近一半，至 95 亿欧元（100 亿美元）。净利润暴跌近三分之二，至 4.31 亿欧元。能源业务（石油和天然气的勘探和生产）以及燃料和原料部门（为化学工业供应）的表现均低于预期。北欧化工超出预期，但仍报告亏损 1100 万欧元。

尽管如此，投资者似乎对斯特恩计划的主旨感到满意。盈利下滑的部分原因只是一年前石油和天然气价格高企时期的回归，而一年前，石油和天然气价格提高了利润。许多人对他在财报电话会议上宣布与德国公司 Interzero 成立合资企业、在德国南部建造欧洲最大的化学品回收分拣厂的消息表示赞赏。奥地利银行 Raiffeisen International 的奥列格·加尔伯 (Oleg Galbur) 认为，一旦周期性行业从中国和欧洲部分地区等大型市场目前的经济放缓中复苏，化学品部门尤其有很大的改进空间。

如果OMV和阿布扎比国家石油公司 ( ADNOC ) 旨在合并北欧化工和阿联酋化工巨头博禄 (Borouge) 的谈判取得成功，该部门的前景可能会进一步光明。这将创建世界上最大的聚烯烃塑料制造商之一，该公司将上市并由OMV和Adnoc平等拥有。 （北欧化工已持有博禄 36% 的股份，阿布扎比国家石油公司已持有北欧化工 25% 的股份。）

斯特恩先生面临的最大挑战将继续是应对其公司与俄罗斯密切业务关系所带来的影响。 2018 年，他的前任雷纳·西尔 (Rainer Seele) 与俄罗斯天然气工业股份公司 (Gazprom) 签署了一份到 2040 年为止的天然气交付协议。斯特恩先生已明确表示，他不打算违背该合同。但他不得不注销25亿欧元的俄罗斯资产，其中包括对北溪2号（从俄罗斯到德国的已废弃天然气管道）的10亿欧元投资。

在最近的财报电话会议上，斯特恩先生煞费苦心地向投资者保证，即使乌克兰政府履行其在 2024 年底前停止通过其领土上的管道运输俄罗斯天然气的意图， OMV也可以履行其天然气输送合同。已做出巨大努力寻找替代天然气供应商，例如挪威。 OMV还与英国能源巨头BP签署了一项协议，通过鹿特丹的一个终端获取液化天然气。七月，斯特恩签署了与罗马尼亚天然气公司 Romgaz 合作的 Neptun Deep 项目，旨在勘探黑海天然气。塑料可能是未来。但OMV的现在还需要一段时间的能量。 ■

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:17:57 GMT /内容/q3c0i2vfb7tciohalcc870hlv35u0kkd https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/02/omv-austrias-energy-major-reimagines-its-future Can Israeli-Emirati business ties survive the Gaza war?

2020年中东商业发生了转变。阿拉伯联合酋长国（阿联酋）和其他一些国家与以色列签署了《亚伯拉罕协议》，使这个犹太国家与其一些阿拉伯邻国之间的关系正常化。以色列游客搭乘有史以来第一条直飞航班涌入迪拜。 2023 年前 8 个月，迪拜接待了近 23 万名来自以色列的游客，比去年同期增加了 73%。如今，特拉维夫的旅行社甚至提供酋长国的成人礼之旅，并在犹太餐厅停留。

阅读我们对以色列和哈马斯之间战争的所有报道

商业往来也蓬勃发展。阿联酋-以色列全面经济伙伴关系协定于四月生效。两国之间的官方贸易预计今年将超过 30 亿美元，而 2019 年则为零。据报道，去年阿布扎比的主权财富基金 Mubadala 向 6 家位于以色列或专注于以色列的风险投资 ( VC ) 基金投资了 1 亿美元初创公司。它还从以色列 NewMed Energy 购买了价值 10 亿美元的海上天然气田股份。金融科技宠儿 Liquidity Group 等以色列科技公司已在阿联酋开设研发中心。以色列和阿联酋的大学在人工智能等领域建立了研究伙伴关系。

由于以色列和哈马斯之间的激烈战争，所有这些进展现在都面临风险。据一位以色列企业家报道，自冲突爆发以来，许多阿联酋联系人都保持沉默。一位往返于迪拜和特拉维夫之间的以色列裔美国投资者担心，即使冲突平息后，阿拉伯公司在与以色列公司进行交易时也会三思而后行。

这对于以色列和阿联酋来说都是不受欢迎的。甚至在加沙发生敌对行动之前，以色列的商业信心就已经下滑。削弱最高法院的改革提议令企业老板们感到担忧。在全球风险投资寒冬中，以色列初创公司在 2023 年上半年筹集了不到 40 亿美元，这是自 2018 年同期以来的最低水平。在 10 月底接受调查的以色列公司中，超过五分之二表示，他们的潜在支持者已取消或推迟了融资投资协议。因此，以色列企业可以利用阿联酋深厚的资本池和进入其国内市场的机会，特别是当他们的国家从敌对行动中恢复过来时，根据调查，这些敌对行动已经影响了五分之四的科技公司。

就阿联酋而言，它觊觎以色列的技术诀窍，这可以加速该国摆脱石油的经济多元化，并帮助其跟上来自其更大邻国沙特阿拉伯的竞争，沙特阿拉伯本身正处于现代化进程的阵痛中（并且，直到加沙战争，正在与以色列建立外交关系）。过去十年，阿联酋的私人投资占国内生产总值的比重有所下降。尽管政府为企业家制定了从加速器计划到信贷担保等各种激励措施，但国际货币基金组织最近指出阿联酋经济的“技术含量薄弱”。大多数新技术企业最终看起来就像是陈旧电子商务企业的模仿者。以色列在数字技术、海水淡化等领域拥有敏锐的技术头脑和自由企业文化，有很多东西可以教给阿联酋人。

因此，持续和解的商业逻辑仍然是合理的。以色列和阿联酋的许多商人都知道这一点，并希望当前的停顿只是这样，而不是崩溃。 ■

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:17:57 GMT /内容/ua3hia5o4pe58rspki3d0jiivru5gjcm https://www.economist.com/business/2023/11/02/can-israeli-emirati-business-ties-survive-the-gaza-war Chinese apps are a mixed blessing for American big tech

去年， Shein 和 Temu 这两个超快时尚新贵在美国展开了一场自相残杀的法律斗争，这两家公司既以 5 美元的连衣裙而闻名，又以淡化自己的中国传统而闻名。总部位于新加坡的 Shein 是两者中知名度较高的一个，他向 Temu 发出了严厉的挑战，指责 Temu 侵犯了其在美国的领土，窃取了其商标，并利用社交媒体影响者来贬低它。总部位于波士顿、由中国电子商务巨头拼多多旗下的 Temu 进行了反击。它指责 Shein 的垄断行为，例如利用其市场力量迫使中国 8,000 多家供应商网络拒绝与 Temu 开展业务。随后，10 月 27 日，路透社报道称，这些公司已暂停敌对行动。

对于西方的观察者来说，这些事情曾经看起来像是一场有趣的余兴节目。但它们表明，中国电子商务的残酷戏剧现在已经来到了美国。 Shein 和 Temu 的命运与美国一些最大的科技公司的命运紧密相连，例如拥有社交媒体帝国的 Meta、谷歌的所有者 Alphabet 以及美国的电子商务巨头亚马逊，更不用说实体店了。沃尔玛等零售商和美国商业街随处可见的一元店。没有人愿意大声说出这一点，但尽管人们都在谈论中美脱钩，但与中国相关的电子商务平台正在以与视频应用程序 TikTok 相同的震慑策略强行进入美国商业。围攻社交媒体。对于数字广告商来说，这是一件喜忧参半的事情。对于折扣零售商来说，这是一个诅咒。对于每个人来说，它可能会改变跨境贸易的经纬。

首先以广告为例。 Meta 在 10 月底公布的第三季度业绩中透露，包括电子商务和游戏公司在内的中国广告商对收入增长产生了“巨大”影响。 Meta 没有透露这些公司的名称，也没有量化它们的影响，但超级侦探们开始了工作。其中一位是布赖恩·维塞尔(Brian Wieser)，他曾是一名广告人，后来成为分析师。五年前，他发现在Facebook平台上销售广告的人和看到广告的人之间的公司数据存在差异，首次引起人们对中国广告商在Facebook上的重要性的关注。直到今年，梅塔才开始承认中国的重要性，并证明他的工作是正确的。研究公司 MoffettNathanson 使用类似的位置数据估计，在截至 9 月份的 9 个月内，Shein 和 Temu 贡献了 Meta 收入增长的近三分之一，即近 30 亿美元（这一数字远低于 Wieser 的估计）。 Alphabet 也收获了巨大的财富。营销公司 Tinuiti 表示，第三季度，Temu 在 Google 购物广告拍卖中与沃尔玛一样是重要竞争对手。一年前，这家刚刚起步的公司还一事无成。

然后是电子商务。亚马逊的平台长期以来一直接待来自中国的廉价商品卖家。他们很少宣传自己的出处。尽管如此，电子商务研究公司 Marketplace Pulse 的创始人 Juozas Kaziukenas 梳理了实际地址，估计许多在亚马逊上销售的商家都位于中国。随着 Shein 和 Temu 的受欢迎程度飙升，其中一些供应商可能会转向他们的平台。目前，卡齐乌克纳斯预计这两家降价公司不会对亚马逊的业务构成实质性挑战，亚马逊的业务规模要大得多，销售的商品种类也更广泛，而且送货速度也远远超过亚马逊。也就是说，如果中国的电子商务有任何指导意义的话，那么这些新兴企业将不会罢休，直到从美国竞争对手手中夺取市场份额，并且不畏对手的影响力。 TikTok 也正在成为在线购物领域不可忽视的力量，利用现场狂欢来吸引购物者，这在中国很常见。莫菲特内森森 (MoffettNathanson) 称这三重攻击是多年来电子商务“最大的破坏性威胁”。

如果亚洲三人组如此强大，为什么美国科技巨头对他们如此保密？对于那些享受广告意外之财的人来说，原因之一可能是对 Shein 和 Temu 的营销热潮能否持续下去的疑问。在利润微薄的大众市场零售业，如果持续太久，在数字广告上投入数十亿美元就会走向毁灭。 Meta 和 Alphabet 可能不想引起人们对收入流潜在波动的关注。

美国的政治阻力也可能正在加剧。国会中的中国怀疑论者对 Shein 和 Temu 的关注与对 TikTok 的关注类似，指责这对快时尚二人组利用了美国法律中的一项例外，即允许价值 800 美元以下的包裹免税进入该国且无需经过任何检查。据估计，根据这一规则，这两家公司负责进入美国的包裹的 30%。堵住漏洞可能会大幅削减这两个平台在美国提供的折扣。此外，他们的算法利用了有关购物者的海量数据。这使他们面临与 TikTok 相同的攻击。

零售公司显然幸免于难的一个风险是中国的镇压。由于总部设在国外，它们不太可能遭受近年来与习近平主席发生冲突的成功中国科技公司的命运。数据收集者 Insider Intelligence 的 Sky Canaves 表示，他们的成功实际上可能正在帮助他们的中国供应商抵消国内经济放缓的影响。她认为这将提高他们在政府中的地位。

猫已经泄露了秘密

目前尚不清楚谢因和特穆为何解决了他们的法律不满，但这肯定会让北京当局松一口气。毕竟，共同战线比数字时装秀上的争斗更有利于国家的海外形象。休战是否意味着他们将减少支出以在市场上超越对方还有待观察。但美国科技巨头正处于新的世界秩序中。他们仍然基本上被排除在中国之外。中国，作为代理，遍布他们的主场。新的竞争无疑让大型科技公司感到沮丧。对于顾客来说，这是一份包装精美的礼物。 ■

RMING 山姆大叔是一项伟大的事业。美国最新的国防预算指定 1,700 亿美元用于采购，1,450 亿美元用于研发 ( R & D )，其中大部分最终落到少数直接与国防部 ( D o D ) 打交道的“主要”承包商手中。美国向乌克兰提供的 440 亿美元军事援助中的一部分以及美国欧洲盟国额外国防开支的一大部分（占主要产品销售额的 5-10%）也将如此。尽管这些金额的增长速度与企业IT支出的增长速度不同，因此实现巨大收益的空间较小，但武器制造商也可以通过长达数十年的巨额合同来避免令人眼花缭乱的损失。

由于冷战结束时的大变动，该行业也高度集中。在 1993 年一次被称为“最后的晚餐”的会议上，时任总统比尔·克林顿 (Bill Clinton) 的国防部副部长威廉·佩里 (William Perry) 对行业老板们表示，产能过剩不再合适，必须进行整合。结果，素数的排名从 20 世纪 50 年代美国的 50 多个减少到了 6 个。卫星供应商数量从 8 个减少到 4 个，固定翼飞机从 8 个减少到 3 个，战术导弹从 13 个减少到 3 个。

过去 50 年来，有保障的定制和疲弱的竞争帮助美国军火制造商的股票跑赢了大盘。国防部今年4月发表的一篇论文发现，2000 年至 2019 年间，国防承包商在股东回报、资产回报率和股本回报率等财务指标方面比民用承包商表现更好。世界日益不稳定意味着更多的资金流向武装部队及其供应商。当俄罗斯于 2022 年 2 月入侵乌克兰以及哈马斯于 10 月 7 日袭击以色列时，通用动力、洛克希德·马丁和诺斯罗普·格鲁曼等主要公司的股东总回报（包括股息）有所上升（见图 1）。

这种舒适的寡头垄断现在正受到两个方面的挑战。一是技术性的。正如乌克兰平原和加沙街道上的坦克战所表明的那样，“地面上的金属”仍然很重要。导弹、炮弹和战斗机也是如此。但这两场冲突也表明，现代战斗越来越依赖于更小、更简单的战术装备以及通信、传感器、软件和数据。第二个挑战是五角大楼努力从军工联合体中获取更大的经济效益。

这两项发展都削弱了 Prime 的巨大竞争优势：他们构建庞大套件和驾驭令人难以置信的采购流程的能力。具有成本效益的创新，例如五角大楼最近宣布的“复制器”项目，旨在尽快让大量小型无人机飞上天空，需要敏捷的工程，而国防巨头“天生没有组织起来”，正如咨询公司科尔尼所言，微妙地说。如果他们想在新时代蓬勃发展，他们就必须重新发现一些在二战后几十年里帮助他们塑造硅谷的创新方式。但到目前为止，他们发现这很困难。

很容易理解为什么主要投资者（及其投资者）喜欢当前的设置。国防部报销主要研发费用，并在此基础上增加 10-15%。这种“成本加成”的方法使公司不必将大量自有资本投入到有风险的项目中，这提供了安全性，但降低了按时、按预算交付产品的动力。建造F -35战斗机的项目于20世纪90年代启动，该项目在过去三年中占洛克希德公司收入的四分之一以上。它的运行晚了大约十年，并且在飞机的整个使用寿命期间将花费美国纳税人高达 2 万美元。

Once in production, newly developed large kit is sold at a fixed price, often for decades. The B -21 stealth bomber currently in development by Northrop Grumman will cost the Pentagon more than $200bn for 100 planes delivered over 30 years. The Columbia Class nuclear-submarine programme made by a subsidiary of General Dynamics will sail from the early 2030s until at least 2085.

Past their prime

The Pentagon's patience with this time-honoured business model is wearing thin. Last year's national-defence strategy summed it up succinctly: “too slow and too focused on acquiring systems not designed to address the most critical challenges we now face”. Instead, it wants to “reward rapid experimentation, acquisition and fielding”. This is forcing the primes to think about how they could build fresh functionality atop their existing platforms, by adding new software, modules, payloads and the like, and to create production processes which can be modified to accommodate innovations.

As Lockheed Martin's chief executive, Jim Taiclet, recently acknowledged, soldiers expect seamless integration of sensors, weapons and systems for battle management such as joint all-domain command and control ( JADC 2), a new concept for sharing data between platforms, services and theatres. Contracting, building and continuously updating such systems will be a struggle for firms that have hitherto produced huge bits of hardware slowly and which, in the words of Steve Grundman of the Atlantic Council, a think-tank, are not “digital natives”.

The primes face another problem. The technology the Pentagon has in mind is not inherently military, observes Mikhail Grinberg of Renaissance Strategic Advisors, a consultancy. Most of the defence giants do have civilian divisions—large ones in the case of Boeing, General Dynamics and Raytheon. But the Pentagon's growing appetite for dual-use technologies means more competition from civilian industry, which is constantly devising new equipment, materials, manufacturing processes and software that could be used for military as well as peaceful ends.

In 2020 General Motors won a contract to supply infantry vehicles. The carmaker has now teamed up with the American arm of Rheinmetall, a German weapons firm, in a deal to furnish military trucks. Other challengers are trying to muscle their way into the military-industrial complex, drawn by the D o D ’s appetite for more diverse systems. Palantir, founded in 2003 to help avert more attacks like that of September 11th 2001, makes civilian and military software that processes the vast amounts of data that modern life and warfare throw up. Elon Musk's Space X sends payloads, including military ones, into orbit and is being paid by the D o D to provide internet access to Ukrainian forces in their fight against Russian invaders.

Big tech is getting in on the action, too. Amazon, Google and Microsoft have targeted defence and security as promising markets, says Mr Grundman. Military procurement is a rare business large enough to make a difference to the tech titans' top lines, which are counted in the hundreds of billions of dollars. The trio, along with Oracle, a smaller maker of business software, are already sharing a $9bn cloud-computing contract with the Pentagon. Microsoft also supplies the army with augmented-reality goggles in a deal that could eventually be worth $22bn.

The Pentagon's new approach is also attracting upstart rivals. Anduril, a firm founded in 2017 solely to serve military needs, has developed Lattice, a general-purpose software platform that can be swiftly updated and adapted to solve new problems. The company also makes a short-range drone called the Ghost, which can be operated by a couple of soldiers. Recognising that to win business quickly it needs to be vertically integrated, it has acquired a manufacturer of rocket engines and is developing an underwater autonomous vessel for the Australian navy.

The wannabe primes and their financial backers still bemoan the barriers to new entrants. Brian Schimpf, Anduril's boss, says that when working with the D o D you get “punched in the face every day”. SpaceX and Palantir both had to fight court battles just to be able to contest military contracts. In June Palantir signed an open letter with 11 other companies, including Anduril, and investors, imploring the Pentagon to remove obstacles to smaller contractors. The letter, which drew on proposals from the Atlantic Council, condemned “antiquated methods” that “drastically limited” access to commercial innovation.

As the national-security strategy shows, the D o D seems keen to move away from procurement antiquity, for example by shifting more risk onto contractors through fixed-price, rather than cost-plus, development contracts. Such developments are causing palpitations among the primes. Boeing's recent financial travails are partly a result of catastrophically underbidding in fixed-price contracts for the KC -46 tanker and Air Force One, which ferries around American presidents.

In contrast, Anduril has dispensed with the crutch of cost-plus of its own accord, and is investing its own capital to make what it thinks the D o D will need. By clinging on to the old model, the primes may be depriving America of the 21st-century defence industry it needs. ■

H iring processes can be thought of as a battle between candour and dishonesty. You might imagine this is a simple fight between truth-seeking firms and self-promoting candidates, and to a certain extent it is. But companies themselves are prone to bend reality out of shape in ways that are self-defeating.

Start with the obvious culprits: job applicants. The point of a CV or a LinkedIn profile is to massage reality into the most appealing shape possible. Everyone beyond a certain level of experience is a transformational leader personally responsible for generating millions in revenue; the world economy would be about 15 times bigger than it actually is if all such claims were true. The average Briton spends four and a half hours a day watching TV and online videos. But the average job candidate uses their spare time only for worthy purposes, like volunteering in soup kitchens or teaching orphans to code.

The cover letter is so open in its insincerity (“When I saw the advertisement for this job, I almost fainted with excitement”) that people are starting not to bother with it. At the interview stage one task facing the firm's recruiters is to winkle out the truth of what a person actually contributed to a project. Those hoary questions about a candidate's weaknesses and failures are there for a reason; no one will bring them up unprompted. Cognitive and behavioural tests are useful in part because they are harder for applicants to game.

在我们新的七部分播客系列 《老板课堂》中，我们的巴图比专栏作家寻找成为更好经理的秘诀。 Episode two looks at hybrid working and episode three explores how to get hiring right.

But a tendency to stretch the truth infects companies as well as applicants. The typical firm will write a job description that invariably describes the work environment as fast-paced and innovative, and then lays out a set of improbable requirements for the “ideal candidate”, someone who almost by definition does not exist. Sometimes—as when ads demand more years of experience in a programming language than that language has existed for—these requirements include an ability to go back and alter the course of history.

Industrialised hiring processes can often reward mindless exaggeration. Services that scan your résumé when you are making an application mark you down if your CV does not match the keywords that appear in the original job advertisement. The message is clear: to get through to the next stage, you have to contort yourself to meet corporate expectations.

Substance can matter less to recruiters than form. One software engineer says she got a 90%-plus response rate with a spoof CV showing apparent spells at Microsoft and Instagram but also boasting, among other things, that she had increased team-bonding by organising the company potato-sack race and “spread Herpes STD to 60% of intern team”. References are so prone to inaccuracy that many firms have a policy of not giving them, fearing legal action from defamed candidates or deceived employers.

Too few firms offer an accurate account of what a position actually involves. Tracey Franklin, the chief HR officer for Moderna, a fast-growing drugmaker—and an interviewee in this week's episode of Boss Class , our new podcast—is a fan of “realistic job previews” ( RJP s). These are meant to give prospective recruits a genuine sense of the negatives and positives of the job, as well as a clear idea of the company's corporate culture. One effective tactic is to lay out, in text or video, what a typical day in the role would look like.

Such honesty can be its own reward. Research has long suggested that RJP s lead to lower turnover and higher employee satisfaction. A paper in 2011 by David Earnest of Towson University and his co-authors concluded that favourable perceptions of the organisation's honesty are the best explanation for why.

The incentives on both sides of the hiring process lean naturally towards glossing reality. If candidates were to give genuinely truthful answers (“I have a habit of making basic but calamitous errors”), many would rule themselves out of jobs. And if firms were to give a warts-and-all description of themselves, many would end up deterring good applicants. But a process designed to uncover the truth about job applicants would run a lot more smoothly if firms were also honest about themselves. ■

; Mon, 30 Oct 2023 17:57:40 GMT /content/0r8ptrp70skj7v7kurr5m9fm70ul5gq1 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/30/how-to-get-the-lying-out-of-hiring America’s economy is booming. Why aren’t its bosses happier?

G ood news about America's economy seems to keep rolling in. In the third quarter gdp expanded by a barnstorming 4.9% in annualised terms. Heading into earnings season, the month or so each quarter when most firms report their latest results, a stream of upbeat economic figures led stockmarket analysts to hold their profit expectations for the quarter steady, rather than trim them as they normally do. Many called the end of America's corporate-earnings recession.

Such optimism now looks justified. Following a hat-trick of consecutive year-on-year quarterly profit declines, America Inc's bottom line is growing again. According to FactSet, a data provider, of the roughly half of big companies in the S & P 500 index that have reported their latest results, 78% have beaten profit expectations (see chart 1).

Yet the mood during the quarterly carnival of conference calls has hardly been celebratory. Plenty of bosses failed to excite investors despite bringing them sound results. The reaction to the performance of big tech was particularly discordant. Alphabet, Google's parent company, heartily beat profit forecasts but saw its share price sink by 10% after investors were underwhelmed by how its cloud-computing division was doing. Meta's warning on macroeconomic uncertainty meant that the social-media empire's biggest-ever quarterly revenue figure went unrewarded by markets. The lingering possibility of a recession and anaemic levels of corporate dealmaking overshadowed banks' profits from lending at higher rates of interest.

Why the gloom? A boom in the third quarter notwithstanding, the future health of America's consumers remains bosses' principal worry. Small wonder. American businesses draw more than a third of their revenues directly from domestic consumers' pockets, according to Morgan Stanley, a bank. Shoppers have seemed indefatigable lately; retail sales grew by 0.7% in September, compared with August. Coca-Cola and PepsiCo both raised their profit guidance for the rest of the year. But recently their growth has been the consequence of price rises rather than selling more fizzy drinks and snacks.

Other cracks are beginning to appear. According to Bank of America, credit- and debit-card data show a downturn in spending in October, compared with a year ago. Last month Americans with student loans had to resume debt payments after a three-year reprieve. In aggregate, spending is now growing faster than real disposable income, eating into savings. At the same time, credit-card and car-loan delinquencies have been ticking up (see chart 2). Consumers tell surveys that they are gloomier about their financial situation—and who can blame them?

That is worrying chief executives. UPS , a delivery firm, said Americans were spending less on goods and more on services, dampening its outlook for profits. Mattel, a toymaker which owns the Barbie brand, among other things, delivered a blockbuster quarter but its outlook for Christmas was a flop with investors. Bosses at Alphabet say that the technology titan's data showed customers hunting harder for deals and offers of free shipping for goods. On Tesla's investor call Elon Musk bemoaned the effect of rising interest rates on consumers' ability to afford the company's electric cars. (Though, as Mr Musk also admitted, some of the carmaker's problems were home-made: “We dug our own grave with the Cybertruck.”) Since the call, Tesla's share price has fallen by 15%, wiping more than $100bn off its market value.

Companies are also closely watching their costs, especially for labour. Margins were boosted by cooling wage inflation across the economy and the summer of strikes is at last winding down. In September Hollywood writers agreed to up pens. In the past week the United Auto Workers ( UAW ) union struck deals with Ford, General Motors ( GM ) and Stellantis (whose biggest shareholder also part-owns The Economist ’s parent company); its members are returning to the factory floor.

But workers, especially in Detroit, have extracted higher wages and other concessions. And the weeks-long stoppages have already cost the carmakers dearly. Stellantis, whose marques include Chrysler and Jeep, said that they shaved $3bn from its sales. GM , which held out the longest of Detroit's “big three”, withdrew its profit guidance for the year. So did Illinois Tool Works, which makes car parts. Even Bosses at Delta Air Lines complained that fewer passengers were landing in Motor City, possibly as a result of the labour unrest.

Happenings farther afield were also weighing on bosses' minds. A refrain in many earnings calls was sadness at the loss of life in Israel and Gaza. Yet for now at least, conflict in the Middle East is not having large financial effects on American companies. A few firms signalled caution—Snap, a social-media firm, said some advertisers in the region paused spending as a result of the hostilities. But corporate America as a whole earns a vanishingly small part of its profits in the volatile region. American bosses who examine the direct risks posed to their business by the war in Gaza are likely to conclude that they are much smaller than the costs of, say, unwinding operations in Russia, let alone the existential worries about America's relationship with China.

Bosses were silent on a bigger long-term threat to earnings: higher interest rates. During the past year the fortunes of big business have diverged from those of smaller firms, especially ones owned by private-equity funds, as they have been largely immune to the soaring cost of capital. Bank of America reckons that more than three-quarters of debt borrowed by S & P 500 firms is both long-term and fixed-rate, compared with less than half in 2007, when ten-year Treasury bond yields last exceeded 5%. Eventually, however, big businesses' debt piles will need to be refinanced at a higher rate of interest, which will squeeze profits. The earnings recession might have ended in the third quarter. But plenty of threats still lie ahead. ■

; Sun, 29 Oct 2023 16:21:39 GMT /content/b8siv205o45nrntf05kh46skla0gjlfa https://www.economist.com/business/2023/10/29/americas-economy-is-booming-why-arent-its-bosses-happier How Mark Zuckerberg escaped a metaverse-sized hole

I T HAS BEEN quite a year for Mark Zuckerberg. The co-founder of Facebook, a social-media Goliath now called Meta, is no stranger to public rebuke. But exactly a year ago even investors appeared to throw in the towel, accusing him of trashing the core business while lavishing money on his pharaonic dreams for the metaverse, a virtual world where he alone appeared to float in a deluded fantasy realm. On the day Meta issued weak third-quarter earnings last year, its share price fell by more than a fifth. Zuck's name was mud.

In the year since it has been rehabilitated. Meta's core business—engaging 3.1bn people a day on Facebook, Instagram and WhatsApp, and selling advertisers access to their attention—is back to rude health. On October 25th the company reported revenues of $34.1bn in the third quarter, up by 23% year on year. That was the sharpest rise since the digital boom of the covid-19 pandemic. Net profits more than doubled to $11.6bn. Meta's share price has risen by 250% since last year's nadir.

In the media, Mr Zuckerberg gets little credit for his business nous. There is more focus on other stuff: his recent passion for martial arts; the cage fight with Elon Musk that never happened; public haranguings, such as lawsuits filed by dozens of American states on October 24th, alleging that Meta intentionally sought to make users addicted to Facebook and Instagram. And yet, in the space of a few months late last year, he made two transformative business decisions that were remarkable for their humility and agility—all the more so, given that he controls 58% of the firm's overall voting rights and barely needs to work, let alone listen to shareholders.

In response to investor pressure, Mr Zuckerberg performed one of the fastest pivots in tech history. Within a fortnight of the third-quarter rout he slashed Meta's spending plans, cut costs and fired staff. And in response to Open AI ’s Chat GPT and the blaze of excitement around generative artificial intelligence (gen AI for short) he launched an internal revolution aimed at using the technology to galvanise Meta's core business. Those manoeuvres reveal a lot about Mr Zuckerberg's leadership style. They may even end up vindicating his faith in the metaverse.

When Mr Zuckerberg realised he had incensed investors, those around him say, he did not panic. He became methodical. As Nick Clegg, a close adviser to Mr Zuckerberg, explains, his boss doesn't like people around him “shouting and yelling”. He prefers, like an engineer, to break down a problem to its component parts and decide on a course of action. In this case, he understood that his long-term focus was at odds with investors' short-term horizons. So he decided to “cut his cloth accordingly”. But he kept many of his long-term investment plans intact, emphasising that they mainly concerned AI , not the metaverse. That emphasis looked shrewd weeks later, when Chat GPT burst onto the scene.

Meta had spent years building up its AI infrastructure. Rather than creating chatbots, it was looking for ways to use AI to improve engagement and make its ad business more efficient, as well as working on mixed-reality headsets for the metaverse. Its top brass soon realised they had all the ingredients—enough data centres, graphics processing units ( GPU s) and boffins—to make the most of gen AI . By February they had worked out what to focus on. By July they had made their Llama 2 large language model available free of charge to developers. In September they announced the first gen- AI -related gadgets, such as smart spectacles. Mr Zuckerberg, for his part, threw himself into the technical nitty-gritty. His competitive instinct awakened. He appears to have been rejuvenated by working on a new technology rather than on the irksome task of cost-cutting.

Making Llama open-source helped turn Mr Zuckerberg from Silicon Valley's villain to its hero. Leigh Marie Braswell of Kleiner Perkins, a venture-capital firm, says startups “really applauded” the move, which helped many develop AI -related businesses. And gen AI may be no less transformative for Meta itself than for Microsoft and Alphabet, owner of Google, whose early bets on proprietary large language models have attracted most of the attention.

Start with engagement. Meta is populating its social-media platforms with chatbot avatars which, it hopes, will increase the amount of time people spend on their feeds, and help businesses interact with customers on messaging apps. Some users call them a bit humdrum, probably because the firm is worried about AI ’s “hallucinations”. Nonetheless, there is potential. Take Jane Austen, an avatar that emulates the author's haughty humour. When asked to describe Mr Zuckerberg, she says he is “bright, driven but perhaps a bit too fond of his own ideas”. She describes the metaverse as a “virtual world where people can escape reality and live their best lives. Dear me, how…unromantic.”

More compelling in the near term is AI ’s potential for advertising. Since Apple restricted Meta's ability to track user data across third-party apps on iPhones, Mr Zuckerberg's firm has had to overhaul its advertising business “down to the studs”, says Eric Seufert, an independent analyst. It has done that fairly effectively, he thinks, by using AI to model user behaviour, rather than tracking the behaviour itself. Last year the company rolled out ad technology called Advantage+, which used AI to automate the creation of ad campaigns. Brent Thill of Jefferies, an investment bank, says that advertisers are impressed. J. Crew Factory, a clothing retailer, has told Meta that the features boosted its return on ad spending almost seven-fold.

Gen AI could take automation further. This month Meta launched tools that let advertisers instantly doodle with different backgrounds and wording. These are baby steps so far, but Andy Wu of Harvard Business School likens them to the start of a gold rush. He says that by creating gen- AI -infused ad campaigns Meta could benefit from the technology as much as Nvidia, the leading maker of GPU s.

Advertisers have their concerns. An ad man at AdWeek NYC , an industry jamboree, described Meta's AI -assisted campaigns as “black boxes” where it controls all the data. That gives it huge influence over a brand's identity, which could be tarnished if the AI goes rogue. Others worry about AI s doing untoward things to boost engagements on Meta's social networks, which could hurt brands by association. Controversies over fake images of the conflict in Gaza on social media illustrate how fraught the terrain remains. Not everyone is convinced by Mr Clegg's insistence that Meta is prepared for this thanks to years of investment in safety and platform integrity.

Some investors, too, remain sceptical. Mark Mahaney of Evercore ISI , another investment bank, reckons that 95% of them would prefer Mr Zuckerberg to spend less on the metaverse. Many are wary of investments in hardware, such as virtual-reality headsets, which tend to generate lower margins than digital products.

Still, Mr Zuckerberg has “not resiled at all” from his long-term bet, Mr Clegg says. Some VR enthusiasts see AI as the metaverse's saviour, helping with the development of crucial hand-tracking technologies and making it cheaper for creators to build three-dimensional worlds. Meta's Smart spectacles, integrated with its chatbot, Meta AI , and built by Ray-Ban, offer a hint of things to come. They capture what the wearer sees, can live-stream it on social media, and answer questions. Asked for sources on critical thinking in business, the AI replied “ The Economist ”. Smart, smarmy or scary? Take your pick. ■
